message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has already been on metformin and lifestyle changes for glycemic control and has seen some improvement. Exenatide is a good choice as a second agent as it helps control blood sugar and also promotes weight loss. Glipizide and Repaglinide promote insulin production and can cause hypoglycemia, while Sitagliptin promotes insulin secretion and only has a modest effect on weight loss.

We refer to PubMed Health for help. Exenatide is a glucagon-like peptide 1 (GLP-1) receptor agonist that can improve glycemic control and promote weight loss. It is a good option for patients with type II diabetes who need to lose weight. Glipizide and repaglinide are sulfonylureas and can increase the risk of hypoglycemia and weight gain. Sitagliptin is a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor which helps lower blood sugar but does not promote weight loss.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has already been titrated to the maximum dose of metformin and has made lifestyle changes, but her glycemic control is still not optimal. Exenatide is a glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonist that enhances insulin secretion and inhibits glucagon release, which can benefit patients with type II diabetes mellitus. Glipizide and repaglinide are both sulfonylureas that increase insulin secretion but are associated with weight gain, which is not desired in this patient. Sitagliptin is a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor that enhances insulin secretion but may not offer enough additional glycemic control in this patient.
